snippet.title: Crafty residents come together to give warm gift
snippet.content: AFTER running for only one week so far, the Guardian Angels Knitting Program has already received over 2000 donations in Nambour. Now in its 19th year, the program has teamed up with the St Vincent de Paul Society to give back to the tens of thousands of Australians facing hardship this winter. From July 17 to August 31, Guardian Pharmacies across the country will distribute knitted garments including beanies, scarves, jumpers and gloves to Vinnies shops and services in a bid to provide each of the 105,000 homeless Australians with warm winter wear. Kym Gillespie, manager at Tim Logan's Nambour Pharmacy, said the community was always supportive of the initiative. "A lot of our ladies are extremely talented, so they like to get an idea of the criteria and add their own creative flair to each item... they are really proud of what they do," she said. "As a business, we like giving back to our community and that's why we try to get ourselves involved and support causes people are passionate about." The donations have been comprised of a variety of items, with the most common including blankets, beanies and jumpers. Ms Gillespie said they currently had a database of around 150 ladies. "There are also a lot of people who can't knit but want to help, so we encourage them to buy wool and we can give that to one of the ladies to turn into something beautiful," she said. "We love everything about this campaign and the knitters and really appreciative of the thought that goes into it." For more information on the program, visit www. .
